Tule.Slo:

Kerndoel 47 De leerlingen leren de ruimtelijke inrichting van de eigen omgeving te vergelijken met die in omgevingen elders, in binnen- en buitenland, vanuit de perspectieven landschap, wonen, werken, bestuur, verkeer, recreatie, welvaart, cultuur en levensbeschouwing. In ieder geval wordt daarbij aandacht besteed aan twee lidstaten van de Europese Unie en twee landen die in 2004 lid werden, de Verenigde Staten en een land in Azië, Afrika en Zuid-Amerika.

Kerndoel 49 De leerlingen leren over de mondiale ruimtelijke spreiding van bevolkingsconcentraties en godsdiensten, van klimaten, energiebronnen en van natuurlandschappen zoals vulkanen, woestijnen, tropische regenwouden, hooggebergten en rivieren.

Kerndoel 50 De leerlingen leren omgaan met kaart en atlas, beheersen de basistopografie van Nederland, Europa en de rest van de wereld en ontwikkelen een eigentijds geografisch wereldbeeld.

IPC:

MP2 Thema: Luchthavens

Aardrijkskunde 2.1

De kinderen weten hoe bepaalde plekken op aarde, zoals luchthavens, de invloed hebben ondergaan van menselijke activiteiten

Aardrijkskunde 2.3

De kinderen weten hoe het leven van mensen wordt beïnvloed door de aard van bepaalde plekken op aarde, zoals luchthavens

Aardrijkskunde 2.4

De kinderen weten meer over weer en klimatologische omstandigheden en hoe deze factoren de natuur en het leven van de mens beïnvloeden

Aardrijkskunde 2.5

De kinderen zijn in staat om geografische termen te gebruiken

Aardrijkskunde 2.7

De kinderen zijn in staat om eenvoudige landkaarten en plattegronden van voor hen bekende plaatsen te maken

Aardrijkskunde 2.8

De kidneren zijn in staat om kaarten met verschillende schaalgroottes te gebruiken om de ligging en geografische kenmerken van bepaalde plaatsen op aarde te vinden

Aardrijkskunde 2.9

De kinderen zijn in staat om secundaire bronnen te gebruiken om geografische informatie te vinden

Aardrijkskunde 2.10

De kinderen zijn in staat om uit te drukken wat de kenmerken zijn van een bepaalde omgeving en de manier waarop daaraan schade wordt berokkend of juist verbetering wordt aangebracht

Aardrijkskunde 2.11

De kinderen zijn in staat om hun aardrijkskundige kennis en begrip onder woorden te brengen, en vragen te stellen en te beantwoorden over geografische kenmerken en omgevingskenmerken

Aardrijkskunde 2.12

De kinderen begrijpen dat elke plek op aarde deel uitmaakt van een bredere geografische context

Aardrijkskunde 2.13

De kinderen begrijpen dat de kwaliteit van de omgeving in stand kan worden gehouden en kan worden verbeterd

Activiteit 1 = Met behulp van de beebot oefenen de leerlingen de juiste volgorde van aankomst op het vliegveld tot het daadwerkelijk opstijgen met het vliegtuig. Ook wordt ingegaan op de verschillende rollen op het vliegveld.

Activiteit 2 = Ze spelen een kwartetspel over het vliegveld.

Activiteit 3 = De kinderen spelen een vliegtuig spel. Ze leren hoe het er op een vliegveld aan toe gaat. En welke Engelse zinnen daarbij passen. Ook zoeken ze een vliegveld op op de computer.

Activiteit 4 = de kinderen bekijken verschillende plattegronden van vliegvelden en beschrijven de kleuren en de outlook

Activiteit 5 = Wat kan je allemaal op een vleigveld doen, wat bevindt zich daar?

Game: Find your partner
Challenge: To ask and answer questions to each other (within the given time set)

Functional language:
Where do you need to go? I need to go to.. You are my partner. You are not my partner, thank you.
Vocabulary:
airport, departure gates, terminal, check in, arrivals, departures, baggage claim, lost property, first aid, toilets, restaurants, tickets, passport control, information, exit, taxi rank, car park, buses, airport shopping, pilot, passenger, air hostess, cleaner, customs officer

Instructions:
- Print the cards (1) at least two times and give every child one or more cards. The cards must be kept as a secret;
- Demonstrate with the whole class first. Put the powerpoint (2) on the smartboard, just as a memorizer. Take a card yourself. Ask the question to a child. Let the child answer in the correct way, corresponding to their card.
- If the response is the same as on their card, then this is their partner. If not, then they need to say goodbye and move on to another child.
- The children then do the same going around the room asking each other the question and giving the answer to find someone with the same card as them.
Variations:
- Set a timelimit;
- When doing the demo, aim to pick 2 pupils with different cards to you, before eventually finding the pupil with the same card! Show the card to the class so they realize that the two cards are the same.

Game: Loop game
Challenge To complete the loop in the right way

Functional language
Who is departing? Who is walking to the departure gates? Who needs a trolley? Who needs to check in? Who is waiting at departures? Who is going to buy Duty Free? Who is eating at a restaurant? Who is standing at passport control? Who is buying a ticket? Who is travelling to the airport? Who is asking for help? Who is collecting their suitcase from baggage claim? Who is having first aid?
Vocabulary:
suitcase, baggage claim, lost property, first aid, toilet, information, asking, exit, standing, line, security, waiting, taxi rank, car park, lost property, airport, travelling, exit, walking, terminal 3, check in, trolley, bus, catch, Duty Free, arrivals, eating, restaurant, buying, ticket,

Instructions
- All children being dealt a (set of) card(s) with a question and an answer to a different question (1)
- Begin with the child who has 'start' reading out their question. The child with the corresponding correct answer is required to read it out. That child then reads their question for another child to answer.
- A loop game is constructed so that the sequence ensures that all questions and answers must be used.
- The loop game is finished when a child has a card with 'the end' on it and when there are no cards left.

Game: Find someone who
Challenge: Challenge to be the first to find an answer to every question

Functional language:
What is on your ticket? The ... is on the ticket
Vocabulary:
destination, departure, flight number, seat number, flight date, barcode, name, airline

Instructions:

Before playing the game you can listen to 'Holiday' by Madonna and fill in the missing gaps (See sheet 5). Open the Prowise Presentation (4) and click on the boarding pass for the song.
- Give every child a copy of the 'find someone who' sheet (1). Give also every child a ticket (2); Open the Prowise Presentation (4) to help with explaining how to carry out the activity.
- Demonstrate with the whole class first. Show a copy of the sheet (1) on the smartboard;
- Choose a child and ask the question 'What is on your ticket?';
- The child responds with 'The ... is on the ticket' and you write their name besides the right column. That means you don't need to ask that question again as you have a name beside it;
- Children then move round the room asking each other the question (3);
- First person to get a name beside each column, finishes the game;
- Feedback from the 'winning pupil' to check they have the right answers at all of the columns
Variations:
- Who can talk to the most people in a certain amount of time?

Time needed: 30 mins

Kerndoel: 47 IPC: 2.3, 2.9, 2.11, 2.12

Description:

* This lesson is only possible for if you have a beebot accesable. (It needs to be booked from ICT centre).
For this activity you need a beebot. Start this activity by finding out what the children already know about airports and sharing information about airports e.g. the different roles and areas that are in the airport. You can do this with help from the Google maps streetview that is especially made for airports (1). You can take a walk through the airport, for example, as a passenger. Practice the words that describe the different areas on the airport. After that you can start with explaining the beebot activity. Put the 'beebot cards airports' (2) on the transparent mat in a random order. Start the activity by giving the children the cards (3) to do the assignments: you need card 1-8. Let one child ask 'Where do you need to go?, let another child tell them what is on the card: 'You need to go from … to …'. The next step is that the children move the beebot from the first area that's on the card to the final area. They need to describe which areas they are passing (in real life) and do that with the beebot. For example: 'I start at the … Then I go to the … After that I pass the … At last I am at the … '. The next step is that the children make a route on their own (cards 10, 11 and 12). The need to describe to another child what they need to do: 'You need to go to …' and then, just like the first part of the activity, describe the areas that they are passing with the beebot. Finally you can use card 13-17. The children need to pass all the areas that the person on the card passes before he gets to his final destination.

Functional language:

Where do you need to go?, You/I need to go to.., You need to go from .. to .., I start at the…, Then I go to.., After that I pass the …, At last I am at the…

Vocabulary:

airport, departure gates, terminal, check in, arrivals, departures, baggage claim, lost property, first aid, toilets, restaurants, tickets, passport control, information, exit, taxi rank, car park, buses, airport shopping, pilot, passenger, air hostess, cleaner, customs officer

Time needed: 15 mins

Kerndoel: 47 IPC: 2.3

Description:

In this activity you play the 'Happy Family' game. Play this game in groups of a maximum of four children. You can print and laminate the Happy Family game a couple of times (1). Explain the game to the children, give an example of a game situation and show them the sentences they need to use while playing Happy Family (2).

Functional language:

I want to ask you something about 'extra services'/'supporting personnel'/ etc.., Could you give me the 'first aid'/'cleaner'/etc please?.., Yes I can give you that card. Here you are., I can't give you that because I don't have that card.

Vocabulary:

Transport to the airport, bus, car, taxi, train, extra services, information, first aid, cash machine, lost property, entertainment, playground, beauty therapy, restaurants, duty free shopping, buy your tickets and go, tickets, check in, passport control, departure gate, cleaner, waitress, supporting personell, security guard, baggage handler, airport employees, pilot, stewardess, customs officer, air traffic controller, back home, arrival, passport control, baggage claim, car park

Time needed: 30 mins

Kerndoel: 47 IPC: 2.5, 2.11

Description:
Start the lesson by opening the prowise presentation (1). Introduce the pupils to the topic (as shown in the presentation). Explain to the pupils that they will be discussing about different types of jobs at airports.
Continue the lesson by playing the song about the airport (as shown on page two of the prowise presentation.) Pupils need to answer the questions as shown in the speech bubbles. After doing so, continue the lesson by demonstrating the activity with the pupils, making sure they understand the concept of the activity. End the lesson with a demonstration of pupils performing the Round Robin activity.

Functional language:
What is the name of the job they sing about in the song?, There are several different jobs at an airport, can you link the right name to the right picture?, Pilots, firefighters, air-traffic-controllers, ground handlers, check-in staff, security officers, Read what has been said by Alice, Lewis and Mathew,

Vocabulary:
I am, He/She is, a pilot, a firefighter, an air traffic controller, a ground handler, check in staff, a security officer.

Time needed: 45 mins

Kerndoel: 47, 50 IPC: 2.9

Description:
* This activity requires a lot of reading and printing out a number of resources. It is suitable for higher able pupils who have got a good command of the English language.

Needs: The game board (printed and laminated) (1), the different cards, pawns (max. 4 children) As many computers as there are children, participating in the game, with the possibility to print. (only for the last question) The paper with all the questions and the answers in the right order. (3)

It's necessary that the children know English words about the airport. And that they have learnt something about what is happening at the airport in Dutch.

In this game the children go by plane around the world. Before you play the game, place the cards with an A, B, C and D in different piles. (4) Place also cards with an aeroplane, star, cloud and sun in different piles. (5)

Then start the game! Take a start card. (2) Where are you going to fly to? This is the trip you are going to make. Look what colour you have and place your pawn on the right land. Decide who is going to start. Put your pawn on A and take the first card. The children have to place cards in the right order. After A go to B. At B they need (6).The children have to read the sentences by themselves. At C They're going to do a role play. At D they are going to look for a picture of the airport where they just landed. And they need to print it. The first one who is taking the printed airport back, is the winner of this game.

(7) is an extra file, you can hang them in your classroom if you want to.

Functional language:

It's your turn, It's my turn, Place the cards in the right order, Well done, Read it out loud, please, Can you tell me what to do, That's right, That's wrong, I don't understand, can you help me?

Vocabulary:

airport, book a vacation, luggage (belt), boarding pass, duty free, shopping area, departure gate, landing, check-in desk, hand in your luggage, get a boarding pass, arrivals, lost property,

kerndoel 42 Oriëntatie op jezelf en de wereld, natuur

De leerlingen leren onderzoek doen aan materialen en natuurkundige verschijnselen zoals licht, geluid, elektriciteit, kracht, magnetisme en temperatuur.

kerndoel 44 Oriëntatie op jezelf en de wereld, natuur

De leerlingen leren bij producten uit hun eigen omgeving relaties te leggen tussen de werking, de vorm en het materiaalgebruik.

kerndoel 45 Oriëntatie op jezelf en de wereld, natuur

De leerlingen leren oplossingen voor technische problemen te ontwerpen, deze uit te voeren en te evalueren.

IPC:

MP2 Thema: Luchthavens

Techniek 2.1

De kinderen weten dat het ontwerp en de uiteindelijke verschijningsvorm van alledaagse gebruiksvoorwerpen in dienst staan van het nut van die producten

Techniek 2.2

De kinderen zijn in staat om producten te ontwerpen en te maken die aan specifieke eisen voldoen

Techniek 2.3

De kinderen zijn in staat om bruikbare plannen te maken

Techniek 2.4

De kinderen zijn in staat om ontwerpschetsen - voorzien van aanwijzingen - te maken en te gebruiken

Techniek 2.5

De kinderen zijn in staat om eenvoudige gereedschappen en apparatuur met enige precisie te gebruiken

Techniek 2.6

De kinderen zijn in staat om mogelijke verbeteringen aan hun ontwerpen en producten te herkennen en uit te voeren

Techniek 2.7

De kinderen kunnen aangeven hoe alledaagse gebruiksvoorwerpen aan de gestelde eisen voldoen

Techniek 2.8

De kinderen zijn in staat om voorstellen te doen ter verbetering van producten die we dagelijks gebruiken
Activiteit 1 = De kinderen leren wat er op een vliegticket staat en ontwerpen hun eigen vliegticket.

Time needed: 2-3 lessons

Kerndoel: 44 IPC: 2.2, 2.3 techniek

Description:

Prior to the lesson you should have internet access available for the children. Open the Prowise presentation (1) and press the ICT button. Talk with the children about what an airline ticket looks like. Have them look up an example of a ticket on the internet. They can write down their findings on a piece of paper. You can go through the presentation by clicking on the words that tell you what to do: 'this', 'here'. In the word web you can write the answers the children come up with. Afterwards, press 'here' to check the answers. You then get to the exercise to put the labels in the correct place. On the next page children can practise sentences in pairs and talk about how to create a ticket. After that, children can design their own airline ticket, either on paper on on the computer. You can also hand out an example (2) to make the design-process a bit easier.

They can present their ticket to the rest of the class and each pair should make two positive remarks on the presentation of another group. On the last page, children can point out what they have learnt by moving the green sign to the right answers. The red crosses go with the wrong answers.

Functional language:

What does an airline ticket look like? This is what they look like, What's on the ticket? The ... is on the ticket, What information needs to be on a ticket? Where do you put the...on the ticket? I put the...here on the ticket, I put it on the right/left side, I put it on the top/bottom, Your ticket is...., I like your ticket because it's...

Vocabulary:

destination, departure, flight number, seat number, date, flight date, barcode, name, airlane, airport, neat interesting, big, very, clear, small, beautiful, colourful, funny
